column11: Fifteen of us travelling as a group visited Jaffna Fort, along with our guide, in the evening of 6th July 2019.  It is listed as an "Arcaeological Protected Monument".  Entry was free.  Open to the public every day from 0800 to 1800 hrs. At the top of the entrance archway is an inscription that reads "ANNO 1680". (Anno - in the year of).  However, according to our guide, it was Portugese who initially built this Fort in 1618. The Dutch, after capturing it in 1658, expanded and rebuilt the Fort to its present shape of a pentagon using Dutch architectural features.  1680 was the year when reconstruction was completed. The extent of the Fort is 62 acres. The width of the wall is 40 feet. Within the fort were an artillery, a church, Queen's palace and administrative garrisons. Most of this historic archaeological structure, together with the buildings and monuments had been destroyed during 30 years of civil war that engulfed the region. Reconstruction commenced after the end of the war.  Quite a bit of rehabilitation work had been carried out since my last visit here in 2016.  However, the many buildings, structures and monuments damaged during the war are still very much in evidence.  Restoration is in progress. The fortified wall surrounding the Fort had been built with coral stones.  Damaged areas are currently under renovation.  Surrounding these ramparts is the moat built to protect it from enemies.  On top of the ramparts is the ruined gallows used to hang prisoners. Though it was sad to see the irreparable damages caused by human conflicts, a walk along the partially rebuilt ramparts helped lessen the heaviness in my heart! Jaffna Fort is listed as an "Archaeological Protected Monument".  Visitors are warned at entry against vandalism.  Writings and Engravings are banned and punishable by law.

column11: Seeing the Jaffna Fort 'as it is' gives real insight into a fort's hostile purpose and the sombre consequences for anyone inside who lost ground. Whilst the walls are beautifully solid, the internal buildings have been reduced to rubble. There is a lot to take in. When we visited an archaeologist on duty at the site told us about a joint Jaffna Uni Archeological Department/UK Durham University initiative. This has only recently revealed "...if Jaffna's history was condensed in a day, the colonial era would only start at just 3 minutes before midnight..'' Using ground penetrating radar (GPR) surveying they know that below the current site sits another preceding the colonial period, and finds show activity well prior to the Portugese, Dutch and British: finds include Roman coins and Chinese porcelain. What a blast?! Some of these finds are on display in cases in a separate chamber in the fort wall, just to the right, if you are facing the entrance from inside the fort. Allow about 1-2 hours to walk around and take in the views, contemplate the past hostilities, the sea birds and the remoteness of it all, and come in the morning if you can. There are WC (traditional). BYO tissues. BYO hat and drinking water. It's about the 30 minute walk from the Jaffna RS or Jetwing Northgate, you can get a tuk tuk there. It was still free when we went (6 August).

column11: Was built by Portugese in 1618 during the invation of Jaffna. The constructions was done under the supervision of Philip de Olivera and is located close to Karaiyur. The fort was named as Our Lady of Miracles of Jafnapatao, due to the various miracles attributed to the statue of Virgin Mary that was placed inside the church within the fort. Later the fort was captured by the Dutch in 1658, under the command of Rijcklof van Goens. During the ruling of the Dutch the fort was expanded and the entrance was renovated in 1860. The fort was taken over by the British ruling in 1795 and remained under the ruling until 1948, where the Ceylon Army then took over the fort. The fort had not only faced ward during the ear where the country was ruled by invasions, and has faced the civil war that prevailed in the country. Today the fort is being renovated, and is still under construction. The whilst the fort has been build mainly from a mix of stones which included granite and coral. A method that can be seen in many building build in the coastal lines of the of the Portugese and Dutch during the same era. Today the re-construction of the fort is done with use of concrete block that have been manufactured to fit the original dimentions of the stones used. The inside the fort is still under construction.

column11: The Fortress of Our Lady of Miracles Jafanapatão, also referred to as Fortress Jafanapatão and now known as the Jaffna Fort, located in the current Jaffna, Sri Lanka. Coated is of strategic importance for meeting the Jaffna Peninsula, on the Palk Strait that separates Sri Lanka from India. The Portuguese presence in Jaffna dates back to 1543 when the local ruler, Cankili I, kidnapped some Portuguese who had wrecked on that coast and then began to pursue his subjects on the neighboring island of Mannar recently converted Christians by St. Francis Xavier. These belonged to a lower caste of fishermen, dedicated to the harvesting of pearls, coveted item by Calicut Muslim traders who often stole them the shots. The conversion had given them the status of Portuguese nationals and the hope of military protection. The Portuguese response would only take place in 1558 when Dom Constantino de Bragança captured Jaffna, forcing Sankili into exile in Trincomalee. For its defense raised a fortification under the invocation of Our Lady of Miracles. In 1570 the Portuguese interests led Periyapulle the throne. This came to be shot down in 1582 by the son of Cankili I Puviraja Pandaram, who initiated an anti-Portuguese politics, allying the Samuri of Calicut and attacking Mannar, without success. In 1591 Portuguese forces marched on Jaffna, knocking the sovereign and replacing it with Ethirimana Cinkam, who reigned until the date of his death, 1617. The baton was handed to Arasakesari and there were three claimants to the succession: the daughter of the ruler, a group mudaliares of pro-Portuguese and Cankili II, nephew of the late. The latter promoted a coup and a palace massacre that led to power under the name Segarasasekaran VIII. To consolidate it, asked the Portuguese recognition in Colombo. Unanswered, and facing internally with Mudaliar pro-Portuguese opposition, the new ruler asked military assistance to naiaques Buccaneers Thanjavur, and allowed the Malabar buccaneers that used a base in Neduntivu, which constituted a threat to Portuguese shipping through Palk Strait. In response, in June 1619, a Portuguese joint force was sent to Jaffna. Naval forces were defeated by the Malabar buccaneers. The land, however, consisting of 5000 men under the command of Philip Oliveira, defeated the Jaffna, capturing the sovereign and leading him to Goa, where he was executed by hanging. Direct members of the royal family who survived, were deported to Goa, having been encouraged various (and even forced) to join as monks and nuns in various religious orders, as a measure to prevent future claims to the throne of that kingdom. With the execution of Segarasasekaran VIII, the line of Aryacakravarti kings who had ruled the kingdom of Jaffna for more than three centuries, was extinguished and the Portuguese began to take over directly the government. At the time, Filipe Oliveira described the inhabitants of Jaffna as "peaceful and weak" and his superior officer, Lanzarote de Freitas, as "quiet, calm and without military experience." In the following decades, there were three rebellions against the Portuguese rule, two led by Migapulle Arachchi. During this period, the Portuguese destroyed Hindu temples and all the Saraswathy Mahal library in Nallur, real repository for the entire literary output of the kingdom. Pursuant to excessive taxes the population decreased and many people moved to Ramanathapuram in India and the Vanni districts further south. The foreign trade of the ancient kingdom had a negative impact, although the elephants, the main item of exports of Jaffna, they were traded for saltpetre with various kingdoms in India and sent to Lisbon. The decline in trade hindered the payment of essential imports, which significantly reduced or ceased. According to Jesuit Father Ferdinand manuscript Queiroz (Goa, 1688), the main source of the Portuguese presence in Sri Lanka at the time, the people of Jaffna was "reduced to extreme misery" during the colonial era portuguesa.1 On June 22, 1658 Dutch forces under the command of Rijckloff van Goens won Jaffna without resistance. The fort was then strengthened and increased. Later, in 1795 the city was conquered by the British, remaining in their possession until 1948. Due to the civil war in Sri Lanka, the fort was the scene of clashes and sieges on several occasions. From 1986 to 1995 it was under control of the Tamil Eelam Liberation Tigers of when it was recaptured by the army of Sri Lanka after a siege of 50 days during "Operation Riviresa". Inside the fortress is the so-called "Queen's House", the embankment, police barracks and several buildings dating back to the Portuguese period.

column11: A visit to the Jaffna fort will always bring the thought "What would this place have been like 30 years ago". Jaffna fort was one of the best preserved Dutch forts in the country until the 1990s when the civil war destroyed most of it. While most of the ramparts have been fully restored, the old dark colored walls clash with the lighter shades of the repaired sections which give you an idea of how much was destroyed. Inside the fort, towards the right when you enter - observe a mound of rubble. Closer inspection will show carvings on the broken columns. This is all that is left of a dutch church that was totally destroyed in the war. Don't miss an evening walk on the ramparts, from one end the Library, Clock tower, Chelvanayagam memorial and the Duraiappah stadium are clearly visible. From the other end enjoy the sunset views across the lagoon with the causeway to the Kayts island slowly disappearing into the approaching darkness. Don't forget to visit the picture gallery at the entry archway which shows how the fort was restored and also is a good place to find out about other historic remains in the Jaffna peninsula.

column11: My wife and I just got back from 11 days in Sri Lanka. As a lot of people have commented online, having a prearranged itinerary and driver would allow us to spend the most time travelling and the least time worrying about organising. We contacted four companies for quotes, looking for a budget option that included travel to Jaffna and a train ride and clear list of what was and wasn’t included. One response was clearly out of our price range, another looked expensive for the hotels offered (and also made some pretty elementary/lazy blunders with the itinerary) so it came down to a choice of two. We chose to travel with Miracle Sri Lanka. This was because they were the quickest to respond (we only decided we would go to Sri Lanka not much more than a week before we were to arrive), had the better price/quality equation on accommodation and because they were best at understanding the type of trip we were after. It’s a cliché, but rather than trying to squeeze us into the itinerary they preferred (and understanding that some things are always “must-sees”) we could tell they had put thought into it and worked with us on a few tweaks here and there – both before arrival and once underway. What we especially liked was that they provided a very full itinerary, there was none of those “relax at the hotel” type days that waste time and decrease the services provided by the travel agent once in-country (money for jam). The list about what activities carried additional charges was clear (and everything was our choice as to whether or not we did it) giving us an honest picture of what was included in the price what wasn’t. This busy itinerary suited us because we wanted to see as much and possible. As a result we did some pretty long days, but we always had the option of doing less and changing the itinerary along the way. The van was very spacious and new (i.e. the suspension coped well with broken roads) with excellent air conditioning. We were eager to see Jaffna, having heard that it had a different feel to other parts of Sri Lanka and was safe now following the end of the “civil” war. Due to our limited time the only way to squeeze in Jaffna was to fly there which was by way of small plane (maybe 9 seats) with limited baggage allowance - but driving is an option and would probably be 8-10 hours by car. The view over the many small farms on the approach to the airport was stunning, Sri Lanka as a whole (and Jaffna in particular) has to have some of the most consistently beautiful scenery of anywhere in the world. Not an ugly landscape to be seen. Jaffna is currently in the process of having a lot of reconstruction work which includes a new rail line. Trains have been absent from Jaffna for so long that many in the area have never seen one in person. Once the trains come, and tourists follow more easily, the area will lose some of the charm it has. There is combat damage in and around the city but to be honest with the passing of time it is becomes hard to distinguish between war ruins and buildings that have fallen into disrepair for other reasons. It was fascinating to see how the city is rebuilding itself, and there were a couple of times we spoke with families who were in the process of repairing their homes as part of the aftermath of the war. We spent two nights in Jaffna, enough time to take in Nallur Kovil, Naguleswaram Temple – where we enjoyed a nice communal vegetarian lunch. It is customary to leave your shoes outside the front door, but unfortunately our shoes got stolen here so make sure you have a bag to take your shoes in with you or do what we did for the rest of the trip and pick up a cheap local pair to use! We also visited Kantharodai Viharaya (interesting and unusual but a small site with no information available in English), Jaffna Fort (quite damaged but a good contrast with Galle), Nilavarai Well (boring) and the Elephant Point memorial (of military significance to Sri Lankans but also conveniently located on the way to Dambulla). On the whole Sri Lankan people love to have their photo taken and it was only very rarely and only in the more touristic spots that someone would stick out their hand for cash. We really enjoyed being able to wander around Jaffna market and just taking photos and seeing the fruits, vegetables and other foods stuffs that we were unfamiliar with. We also took a trip out to Point Pedro (the northern most tip of Sri Lanka) which is only of interest to the factoids among us but a real highlight was stopping in a town along the way which was commemorating a religious day with the local women gathering on the beach in colourful saris as the sun went down. A beautiful and tranquil atmosphere. We had a fairly solid couple of days, but there are also some other sites which would be worth another day or two of sightseeing or longer if you have time to settle into the local rhythm. We enjoyed Jaffna and if you have the time we think it is worth a look. The rest of our trip was excellent, albeit pretty much the same sort of route that most travellers take so no point covering again what has already been done ad infinitum. After the cultural triangle (we found the local guide “Asanka” at Anuradhapura to be genuinely exceptional and who made our visit to be something special) it was on through Kandy, Nuwara Eliya, Haputale, Ratnapura, and Bentota, before quickly back to Colombo before flying out. We could not be happier with the service provided by Miracle Sri Lanka. A driver really is only there to get you from A to B (hence “driver” rather than “guide”) but we were fortunate that our rookie driver was being trained by a more experienced driver/co-ordinator named Lahtif. Lahtif truly went above and beyond what we had any right to expect, putting in many long days, answering our endless questions on the road, patiently stopping the vehicle every time we wanted yet another photograph of a highland tea plantation, and generally ensuring that we were always happy and enjoying our trip. It was clear that he loves his country very much and loves his fellow Sri Lankans irrespective of status or religion. All the Staff at Miracle Sri Lanka gave us the personal touch and really took great care of us. My wife and I have travelled to over 140 countries combined and this type of hospitable service is a rarity. That is why we recommend Miracle Sri Lanka without hesitation. We’re sure they will grow and we hope they are able to maintain the personalised touch as they get bigger. This business philosophy built on the service we received from the company director, Ashad Wahab, whose hospitality on our arrival into Colombo at 2am really set the tone for what was to come. As budget travellers our accommodation typically met or exceeded our expectations – the places were not always centrally located (largely irrelevant with our own van) but all had something unique or special about them, whether it was a pool, a great view, or just interesting design. The only exception to this was the Amarasinghe Guest House Haputale. Now we accept most the blame for this. Miracle does not normally put its guests there but because there was so little time between when we actually confirmed the booking with Miracle and our arrival (3 days) we did not get Miracle’s first choice accommodation in Haputale. And to be honest if travelling independently we probably would have picked it anyway because Lonely Plant Sri Lanka raves about it. We have absolutely no idea why and Lonely Planet is dead wrong on this one (for this and other reasons we are starting to fall out of love with LP!). Everything about the guesthouse smacked of cheapness and penning-pinching; from the padlock on our door through to the cold shower (good water pressure though) to the food – all of which was wrapped up in a retirement village ambience. Anyhow, we’ve slept in worse and it was only for one night. We loved Sri Lanka, the friendliness, humility, sincerity and helpfulness of the people (and their beautiful smiles), the relative ease of getting around, the brilliant and delicious food (the fruit in Jaffna was peerlessly superb) – the spicier the better, the wild elephants and monitor lizards we saw along the roads, the concentration of sites spanning Buddhism, Hinduism, Islam and Christianity and the various colonial powers...and even (oddly) the maniacal private buses that storm through traffic like dinosaurs with roid-rage and make you appreciate every other vehicle on the road by comparison. Sri Lanka was one of the friendliest, welcoming and safe places that we have encountered.

column11: When it was intact , the Jaffna Fort was a showcase Dutch Fort, with beautiful fortifications, buttresses, the famous Kruys Kirk , clock tower, gallows, Governor's Residence etc.  The setting too is beautiful -- overlooking the lagoon, a great place to be at dawn and dusk. Meanwhile, it is still possible to admire and enjoy the restored parts, the setting and the exhibition of pictures --- for those who remember the Fort as it was, it is also a sad reminder of the destruction this war inflicted.

column11: Jaffna Fort is huge and imposing on the foreshore of Jaffna and is currently being restored back to 'New' condition. If you climb up onto the ramparts the view (and breeze) are fantastic. While this fort is huge in size, it lacks the buildings and charm of Galle and Mannar forts, although there are a few interesting points. The Dutch church was reduced to a MASSIVE pile of rubble from bombing during the conflict and lies as a stark reminder of those times - one can only be in awe of the incredible size the walls must have been. The only recognisable feature being a blue doorway sitting on the top like it has dropped from the heavens. Next to the remains of the church is the remains of the 'Queen’s Palace', complete with a perfect row of Corinthian pillars on the verandah and much evidence of heavy fighting with bullet holes and skirmish marks all over it. Other than a some tunnels to explore, a wall and a few bits and pieces of stonework with treeroots wrapping themselves around it, there isnt much else to see at this point in time. If you love history and architecture you will find this interesting. The waterfront of the fort is a popular sunset spot with the locals.
